SENT.plain: This study examined the effect of prolonged postischemic halothane administration on outcome from transient focal cerebral ischemia in rats
Conscious normothermic rats were subjected to 75 minutes of filament middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO)
Animals were then divided into two groups
The Awake group (n = 15) remained awake following ischemia
The Halothane group (n = 15) received 1.3-1.4% halothane for 5 hours after onset of recirculation
In both groups, brain temperature was maintained at 37.5 degrees C during ischemia and the first 22 hours of recovery
Seven days after ischemia, the severity of hemiparesis and cerebral infarct size were examined
Neurologic scores did not differ between groups (Awake = 1+/-2.75; Halothane = 2+/-2; p = 0.772, median +/- interquartile range)
Neurologic scores and total infarct volumes were correlated (R = 0.653; p = 0.0004)

Cortical (Awake = 76+/-57 mm3; Halothane = 90+/-57 mm3; p = 0.494, mean +/- standard deviation), subcortical (Awake = 71+/-33 mm3; Halothane = 80+/-35 mm3; p = 0.472), and total (Awake = 147+/-88 mm3; Halothane = 171+/-91 mm3; p = 0.477) infarct volumes were not significantly different between groups
The data indicate that postischemic halothane administration offers no benefit in ameliorating damage from focal cerebral ischemia
This suggests that the neuroprotective effect of halothane observed in other studies is consistent with influences on intra-ischemic pathophysiology only
